**Course Catalog**  
**Description**

This course will explore how new media affects the development and change of global civil society from different perspectives. From the changes of museum activism, cinemactivism, slacktivism, media activism, activist journalism, and gamification, we can see how culture has been involved in social issues and initiatives through various digital forms.

Furthermore, from a historical perspective, civil society's concept, definition, and development are reviewed. Then, starting from the historical context, look at the formation and transformation of global civil society. What role did the medium/new medium play in this history?

How relevant issues and ideas are delivered/not delivered in various ways. The development of the Internet and the intervention of new media, how to become a new interactive mechanism in the public sphere, and how to become a powerful tool for communication/a new form of communication obstacle at various stages. What is the relationship between mainstream media, online media, and civil society? Furthermore, how it has caused considerable changes in the intervening years. This course combines theory and practice. In theory, the relevant theories and history of civil society and activism, policy formulation and development processes, media and communication theories are introduced and are based on actual case study analysis.

On the practical side, through case studies of success and failure, students will explore the essential elements of advocacy for new media and social issues (including identifying campaign goals, target audiences, designing response forms, understanding message structures, and multi-media channel communication methods), and Learn how to influence the political system through new media. Classes are based on lectures, interactions, case studies, group discussions, and dialogues. Students in this course will understand the development of civil society and related theories from the perspective of history and further understand the current situation of contemporary civil society from two significant approaches.

**Course task(10%):**

Active participation is crucial to your learning, and others enrolled in the class. Active participation includes contributing to the discussion by engaging with your classmates, posing questions relevant to the readings, lectures, and comments, listening when others are presenting (including the instructor, classmates, and guests).

**Weekly news** **Group** **Presentation(10%):**

Each group takes turns introducing activist cases (in Taiwan) related to the topic of the week. PPT has been submitted on the moodle at least 48 hours prior to the class. Each group has 5 minutes presentation with no more than 6 slides. 

**Midterm Group** **Presentation(25%):**

Each group will introduce its initial action plan to the class. The presentation includes a topic, overview, context, questions, methods, funding, communication, and effectiveness. _PowerPoint submission deadline_: 13 April 2022.

**Final Group Presentation(30%):**

Each group will present its final action plan to the class. Students are encouraged to be creative in helping the class understand what issues they have done/ advocated during this semester. While these can be Powerpoint presentations, they may also take the form of a speech, rap, video, website, or other means of conveying what was done. The last class sessions (30 May) will be dedicated to presentations. _PowerPoint submission deadline_: 28 May 2022; **FINAL PROJECT COMPLETION REPORT submission deadline: 4 June 2022.**

**\*\*\*Intra-Group Member Peer Evaluation: submission deadline: 4 June 2022.**
